object-oriented language, not a C-style OOP language. The only
object-oriented features of C are pointers and reference semantics.
The language uses object and class terminology, the keywords are
mutable and non-mutable, reference and value, and so on, but those
are all concepts related to OOP, not to how you use the language.
A language can use the same words with a different meaning than
you're actually used to, but I've never seen C use the same words
with a different meaning than its usage in the rest of the C
family.

A:

The idea is to turn the sentences into questions, which gives you a choice between an affirmative and negative form.

(I) This place is awful!
(II) This place is amazing!
(III) This place is terrible.
(IV) This place is fantastic!
(V) This place is terrible.
(VI) This place is not terrible.

Now change the last word into a negative by adding the following prepositions to it and/or changing the suffix:

(VII) not awful, not amazing, not terrible
(VIII) not awesome, not incredible, not terrible
(IX) not awful, not terrible
(X) not bad, not good
(XI) not terrible, not good
(XII) not terrible

In most cases you can also use the negatives of adjectives (i.e. the opposite) in place of (VII-XII).
